RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the large white Ford pickup truck: the large white Ford pickup truck
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.marked United States/Mexican Border Patr: marked United States/Mexican Border Patrol vehicles
RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the patrol car: marked United States/Mexican Border Patrol vehicles

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the large white Ford pickup truck: Vehicle in which Michael Brett Jacquinot was a passenger during the United States/Mexican Border Patrol stop, bearing a Kansas license plate and appearing suspicious due to its presence in Big Bend National Park on a Sunday morning. It was stopped 70 or 80 miles from the United States/Mexican Border after being followed for approximately fifteen minutes.
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas Highway 385: Highway notorious for smuggling activities, with a reputation that adds to the reasonableness of the agents' suspicion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States/Mexican Border Patrol: Law enforcement agency responsible for border control and patrol, with agents such as Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Big Bend National Park: Location along the United States/Mexican Border where vehicle sensors are located, a recent narcotics smuggling operation originated, and which has typical traffic patterns that can indicate suspicious activity
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Alpine, Texas: Location where United States/Mexican Border Patrol Agents Andrew P. Graham and Jay Snodgrass were stationed, and area from which Big Bend National Park typically hires contractors, with recent narcotics smuggling taking place through the area destined for locations in Kansas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Marfa Sector Area Operations Center: Previous work location of United States/Mexican Border Patrol Agent Jay Snodgrass
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Laredo, Texas, border area: Previous work location of United States/Mexican Border Patrol Agent Jay Snodgrass
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.marked United States/Mexican Border Patr: Vehicles used by United States/Mexican Border Patrol agents for patrol and surveillance
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.a late model four-door sedan: Vehicle observed by United States/Mexican Border Patrol, carrying an older Anglo couple
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.the computer-system: System used by the United States/Mexican Border Patrol for registration information, which experienced problems during the pursuit of the large white Ford pickup truck
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S. District Court: Court responsible for making decisions based on guidelines from the 5th Circuit Court regarding United States/Mexican Border area cases, and found that the totality of the circumstances provided United States/Mexican Border Patrol with reasonable suspicion to warrant the stop of the large white Ford pickup truck
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.5th Circuit Court: Court providing guidelines for the U.S. District Court in cases related to the United States/Mexican Border area
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States Government: Government under which the United States/Mexican Border Patrol operates
